author: Jacqueline Lynch
title: No Fixed Address: WA homelessness highlighted in exhibition
text:
Map: Bunbury 6230 
It was curiosity that prompted Bunbury photographer Kate Heaslip to open her eyes and ears while walking around Bunbury and Busselton and to speak to people sleeping rough overnight. 
The artist was so touched by the stories of people on the streets — including one man who said he could no longer cope without a home — it led to an idea for a photo exhibition to highlight homelessness in the South West, and the plight of those affected by it. 
However, while Heaslip took pictures of the people she met, she said the photographs themselves were not the most important reason she started the project. 
"I didn't want to do this voyeuristically," she said. 
"I actually wanted to know what was happening and how it was [for them]." 
Heaslip talked to each person she met and helped out with small gestures of kindness. 
She gave a blanket, a pillow and clothes to one man who was particularly struggling. 
"He said 'can you find me a home? I've been living like this for four years and I can't do it anymore'," she said. 
Another man told her he had been on the streets for 33 years. 
Ms Heaslip said the people she met were supportive of her project. 
"Time after time it was [them saying] 'thank you, people don't see us'," she said. Photo: The exhibition of photos is on display at Bunbury Regional Art Gallery until March 5. (Supplied: Kate Heaslip) 
Homelessness is a big problem in the South West. 
Salvation Army's Lieutenant Harriet Farquah said she had seen an increase in primary homelessness in Bunbury — where people have no conventional accommodation. 
She said there were reports of 50 to 100 people who were "visibly sleeping rough". 
However, Ms Farquah said episodes of kindness towards the homeless population like that shown by Heaslip went a long way. 
"When people are homeless, they often feel like society has turned their back on them and that they're worthless," she said. 
"Just having someone do the simple act of saying hello can make people feel human again." 
Heaslip's exhibition, No Fixed Address, will be on display at Bunbury Regional Art Gallery until March 5.
